word.description:
{京} is short for Beijing (second character of the name, meaning *capital*), and {菜} is *vegetable* or *dish* or *cuisine*. So {京菜} is Beijing cusine or literally *capital cuisine*.

**Graphics Credit**

[TUBS, CC BY-SA 3.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0), via [Wikimedia Commons](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Beijing_in_China_(%2Ball_claims_hatched).svg)

description: [Beijing cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beijing_cuisine) is influenced both by the imperial court menus of Beijing (the most famous probably is [Peking duck](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peking_duck)) and food of the surrounding provices.

word.description:
{粵} is generally synonmyous with Cantonese (although technically it refers to Yue language of which includes both Cantonese and Taishanese), and {菜} is *vegetable* or *dish* or *cuisine*, so {粵菜} is *Cantonese cuisine* or *Yue cuisine*.

**Books**

Grace Young's most recent book, *Stir-frying to the Sky's Edge*, features recipes and anecdotes from the Chinese global diaspora.

description:
[Cantonese cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cantonese_cuisine), one of the [eight great cuisines of China](https://thewoksoflife.com/8-chinese-cuisines/), is the food of [Guangdong province](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong). The mysteriously mangled English name Canton sometimes refers to the provice, sometimes to the capital [Guangzhou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangzhou), and even sometimes to a [river](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pearl_River) in the province.

More precisely it's the food of Cantonese speakers, and there are other distinct cuisines in the region such as [Chaozhou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaozhou_cuisin) and [Hakka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hakka_cuisine))

Cantonese cooking is known for minimal seasoning and showcasing the flavor of fresh ingredients via steaming and stir-frying. The taste of properly stir-fried dishes is known in Cantonese as {鑊氣}, pronounced *wohk hei* and often spelled *wok hay*, translated by [Grace Young](https://www.graceyoung.com/) as *breath of a wok* ({鑊} is a *wok*, and {氣}, pronounced *qì* in Mandarin, is well known to mean *vital energy* but also just denotes *air* or *gas*).

There are some mildly spicy items (salt and pepper seasoning, curry dishes), but if you want something that'll make you sweat, head over to Hunan or Sichuan cuisines.

**Graphics Credit**

[TUBS, CC BY-SA 3.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0), via [Wikimedia Commons](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Guangdong_in_China_(%2Ball_claims_hatched).svg)

word.description: {潮州} is [Chaozhou](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaozhou), and {菜} is *vegetable* or *dish* or *cuisine*, so 潮州菜 is [Chaozhou cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaozhou_cuisine).

description:
[Chaozhou cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaozhou_cuisine)is also known as Chiuchow cuisine or Teochow cuisine or Chaoshan cuisine (Chaoshan is the area surrounding the city of Chaozhou on the eastern end of Guangdong provice). Chaozhou cuisine is distinct from Cantonese cuisine (sometimes labeled a subset), but Chaozhou-style [fun guo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fun_guo) is a standard Cantonese dim sum item.

**Graphics Credit**

[TUBS, CC BY-SA 3.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0), via [Wikimedia Commons](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Guangdong_subdivisions_-_Chaozhou.svg)

word.description: {福建} is the full name for Fujian (fūk gin in Cantonese, fú jiàn in Mandarin), but is an alternate {閩} is a short name [Fujian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fujian), and {菜} is *vegetable* or *dish* or *cuisine*, so {閩菜} is *Fujian cuisine* or *Min cuisine*.

description:
[Fujian cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fujian_cuisine), the food of the [Fujian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fujian) province and one of the [eight great cuisines of China](https://thewoksoflife.com/8-chinese-cuisines/).

**Graphics Credit**

[TUBS, CC BY-SA 3.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0), via [Wikimedia Commons](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Fujian_in_China_(%2Ball_claims_hatched).svg)

word.description: {湘} is the [Xiang River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiang_River) in Hunan and also an abbreviation for [Hunan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunan), and {菜} is *vegetable* or *dish* or *cuisine*, so {湘菜} is *Hunan cuisine* or *Xiang cuisine*.

description:
[Hunan cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunan_cuisine) is one of the [eight great cuisines of China](https://thewoksoflife.com/8-chinese-cuisines/). Hunan cuisine is known for a characteristic spiciness, although it is a dry spiciness, different from the numbing spiciness ({麻辣} of [Sichuan cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunan_cuisine)).

**Books**

Revolutionary Chinese Cookbook: Recipes from Hunan Province by [Fuschia Dunlop](http://www.fuchsiadunlop.com/).

**Graphics Credit**

[TUBS, CC BY-SA 3.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0), via [Wikimedia Commons](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Hunan_in_China_(%2Ball_claims_hatched).svg)

word.description: {秦} is *Qin*, another name for the region (birthplace of the [Qin dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qin_dynasty), China's first imperial dynasty), and {菜} is *vegetable* or *dish* or *cuisine*, so {秦菜} is *Shaanxi cuisine* or *Qin cuisine*.

description:
[Shaanxi cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaanxi_cuisine), influenced by neighboring Shanxi and Sichuan provinces, is characterized by an abundance of lamb dishes and fragrant spiciness (香辣). It's most well-known dish is probably the so-called [Chinese hamburger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roujiamo) (more like a pita sandwich), popular throughout China and increasingly outside.

**Books**

[Xi'an Famous Foods](https://www.xianfoods.com/book) by Jason Wang recounts the history and Shaanxi recipes (Xi'an is the capital of Shaanxi) of his New York-based restaurants.

**Graphics Credit**

[TUBS, CC BY-SA 3.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0), via [Wikimedia Commons](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Shaanxi_in_China_(%2Ball_claims_hatched).svg)

word.description: {滬} is another name for *Shanghai*, and {菜} is *vegetable* or *dish* or *cuisine*, so {滬菜} is *Shanghai cuisine* or *Hu cuisine*.

description:
[Shanghai cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shanghai_cuisine)

**Books**

*Land of Fish and Rice: Recipes from the Culinary Heart of China* by [Fuschia Dunlop](http://www.fuchsiadunlop.com/) covers the cuisine of [Jiagnan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jiangnan), the region surrounding Shanghai.

**Graphics Credit**

[TUBS, CC BY-SA 3.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0), via [Wikimedia Commons](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Shanghai_in_China_(%2Ball_claims_hatched).svg)

word.description: The Chinese characters for Sichuan, {四川}, is *four rivers* ({四} is *four* and {川} is (and looks like) *river*). {菜} is *vegetables* but also more generally type of *dish* or *cuisine*, so {四川菜} is *Sichuan cuisine*. But it's generally shortened to {川菜}.

description:
[Sichuan cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan_cuisine), one of the great [eight great cuisines of China](https://thewoksoflife.com/8-chinese-cuisines/), is the food of [Sichuan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sichuan) province (otherwise known in English as Szechuan), famous, or notorious, for its [spiciness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mala_(seasoning)), although the cuisine features a variety of flavors and spice levels.

**Books**

*The Food of Sichuan* by [Fuschia Dunlop](http://www.fuchsiadunlop.com/) is a compendium of Sichuan recipes and reminiscences. I also recommend her memoir.

**Graphics Credit**

[TUBS, CC BY-SA 3.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0), via [Wikimedia Commons](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Sichuan_in_China_(%2Ball_claims_hatched).svg)

word.description: {台} is an abbreviation for Taiwan, and {菜} is *vegetables* but also more generally type of *dish* or *cuisine*, so 台菜 is *Taiwan cuisine*.

description:
Taiwanese cuisine, thoughly largely derived from waves of migration from mainland China, from the early [Hakka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hakka_cuisine), to those who fled the Chinese civil war at the end of World War II, and later, is also influenced by the [indigineous people](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taiwanese_indigenous_peoples) of Taiwan, [Japanese cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_cuisine) (dating from the period of Japanese rule), and various international sources.

**Graphics Credit**

[TUBS, CC BY-SA 3.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0), via [Wikimedia Commons](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Locator_map_of_the_ROC_Taiwan.svg

word.description: {滇} is an abbreviation for Yunnan (it's a lake in the province), {菜} is *vegetables* but also more generally type of *dish* or *cuisine*, so 滇菜 is *Yunnan cuisine* or *Dian cuisine*.

{點} is *a bit* or *a touch*, and {心} is *heart* (the character looks like a heart), so {點心} can be translated as *a bit of heart* or *a touch of heart* or *touching the heart* (Grace Young in [The Breath of a Wok](https://www.graceyoung.com/cookbooks/cookbook-2/) translates it as *a dot on the heart*). Anyway, the origin of the term is debated.

{點} is also the first character in *why* ({點解} dím gáai) and *o'clock* {(點鐘) dím jūng}. {心} is also the second character in *be careful!* ({小心} síu sām), *happy* ({開心} hōi sām) and the vegetable *choy sum* ({菜心} choi sām).

images.place: New Asian BBQ, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
[Dim sum](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dim_sum) are shared small dishes or steamer baskets of dumplings and other typically bite-sized foods.

**History**

Dim sum dishes originated from all over China and some even have Western influences, but dim sum as a Hong Kong and [Cantonese cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cantonese_cuisine) (The English spelling is close to the Cantonese pronunciation *dím sām*) originated in the *yum cha* (drink tea) tradition of travelers stopping at teahouses for tea and snacks along the Silk Road (so dim sum was an early version of truck stop food).

Dim sum is known for being served in on carts in large restaurants, but these days it can be found in a variety of settings ranging from banquet-sized restaurants to cozier Hong Kong-style cafes (cha chaan teng) and ordered off a menu.

**Books**

[The Dim Sum Field Guide](https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/533493/the-dim-sum-field-guide-by-carolyn-phillips/) by Carolyn Phillips is an illustrated overview of dim sum, Dim Sum: The Art of Chinese Tea Lunch by Ellen Leong Blonder is an illustrated collection of recipes and some background info. Dim Sum by Janice Wong and Ma Jian Jun presents recipes for traditional and new dim sum with a focus on the flour used in the wrappings. The [Nom Wah Cookbook](https://nomwah.com/cookbook/) by Wilson Tang features recipes from the Nom Wah Tea Parlor, a New York Chinatown institution, and profiles the immigrants and their descendants who've kept multi-generational businesses alive in Chinatown. Grace Young's The Wisdom of the Chinese Kitchen includes some dim sum recipes.

**Books for Kids**

[Dim Sum for Everyone!](https://gracelin.com/dim-sum-for-everyone/) by Grace Lin is an illustrated dim sum family outing. Dim Sum Time by Sin Siu Tang and Andrew Sun teaches Cantonese dim sum phrases.

word.description: {港} the second character of *Hong Kong*, and {式} is style, so {港式} is *Kong-style*.

description:
[Hong Kong cuisine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong_cuisine) is of course largely Chinese (in particular, Cantonese) but it has benefited from a continuing influx of other Asian and Western influences, resulting in some original takes, like Hong Kong-style French toast, Hong Kong-style iced lemon tea, Hong Kong-style egg tarts...

**Graphics Credit**

[TUBS, CC BY-SA 3.0](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0), via [Wikimedia Commons](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Hong_Kong_in_China_(%2Ball_claims_hatched).svg)

word.description:
{素} is typically used in conjunction with a term to mean *vegetarian*, e.g. {素菜} (sou choi) is *vegetarian dish*, {素餐} is *vegetarian meal*, {素食} is *vegetarian food*.

{素} also means *simple*, *plain*, or *clear*, so {素月} is a bright and clear moon, {素顏} is *face without makeup*, and {素數} is *prime number*.

images.place: Chef Kenny's Vegan Dim Sum, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
With a long history of Buddhism and people just not able to afford meat, Chinese cuisine traditionally excels in flavorful and textured vegetable dishes and also “mock” meats made from tofu and wheat gluten (yes, gluten).

**Books**

[Vegetarian Chinese Soul Food](https://mychinesesoulfood.com/vegetarian-chinese-soul-food/) by [Hsiao-Ching Chou](https://mychinesesoulfood.com/about/)

images.place: New Asian BBQ, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
Cantonese cuisine and other coastal Chinese cuisines are known for fresh seafood, exemplified by how the word for *seafood* {海鮮} joins *ocean* {海} and *fresh* {鮮} is *fresh*, so *seafood* is *ocean fresh*.

And {鮮}, which also by itself means *seafood*, consists of left and right radicals {魚} and {羊} which mean *fish* and *fresh*, respectively.

**Similar Words**

{海} is also part of {海菜} (*ocean vegetable*, i.e. *seaweed*).

{鮮} is also part of {新鮮} (*new fresh*, more commonly used as a standalone word for *fresh*).

word.description: {新} is *new*, and {菜} is *dish* (or *vegetable* or *cuisine*), so 新菜 is *new dish*.

images.place: Hong Kong Garden, Las Vegas, Nevada

description: This category is updated with the latest dishes added to this app.
